org.numenta.nupic.network.sensor

Class Publisher

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.numenta.nupic.network.sensor.Publisher

  • public class Publisher
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides a clean way to create an rx.Observable with which one can input CSV Strings. It ensures that the underlying Observable's stream is set up properly with a header with exactly 3 lines. These header lines describe the input in such a way as to specify input names and types together with control data for automatic Stream consumption as designed by Numenta's input file format. NOTE: The Publisher.Builder.addHeader(String) method must be called before adding the publisher to the (i.e. Sensor). Typical usage is as follows: 
     
    In the case of manual input
    
 Publisher manualPublisher = Publisher.builder()
     .addHeader("timestamp,consumption")
     .addHeader("datetime,float")
     .addHeader("B")
     .build();
 
 ...then add the object to a SensorParams, and Sensor
 
 Sensor> sensor = Sensor.create(
     ObservableSensor::create, 
         SensorParams.create(
             Keys::obs, new Object[] { "your name", manualPublisher }));
             
 ...you can then add the "sensor" to a Layer
 
 Layer l = new Layer<>(n)
     .addSensor(sensor);
     
 ...then manually input comma separated strings as such:
 
 String[] entries = { 
     "7/2/10 0:00,21.2",
     "7/2/10 1:00,34.0",
     "7/2/10 2:00,40.4",
     "7/2/10 3:00,123.4",
 };
 
 manual.onNext(entries[0]);
 manual.onNext(entries[1]);
 manual.onNext(entries[2]);
 manual.onNext(entries[3]);
    Author:
    David Ray

      • builder

        public static Publisher.Builder<<any>> builder()
        Returns a builder that is capable of returning a configured PublishSubject (publish-able) Observable
        Returns:

      • onNext

        public void onNext(java.lang.String input)
        Provides the Observer with a new item to observe.

        The Observable may call this method 0 or more times.

        The Observable will not call this method again after it calls either #onCompleted or onError(java.lang.Throwable).

        Parameters:
        t - the item emitted by the Observable

      • onComplete

        public void onComplete()
        Notifies the Observer that the Observable has finished sending push-based notifications.

        The Observable will not call this method if it calls onError(java.lang.Throwable).

      • onError

        public void onError(java.lang.Throwable e)
        Notifies the Observer that the Observable has experienced an error condition.

        If the Observable calls this method, it will not thereafter call onNext(java.lang.String) or #onCompleted.

        Parameters:
        e - the exception encountered by the Observable

      • subscribe

        public Subscription subscribe(<any> observer)
        Subscribes to an Observable and provides an Observer that implements functions to handle the items the Observable emits and any error or completion notification it issues.
        Scheduler:
        subscribe does not operate by default on a particular Scheduler.
        Parameters:
        observer - the Observer that will handle emissions and notifications from the Observable
        Returns:
        a Subscription reference with which the Observer can stop receiving items before the Observable has completed
        See Also:
        ReactiveX operators documentation: Subscribe
